. ## INSTRUCTIONS AND ADVICE FROM JAY IN THIS COMMENT
add-examples-symlinks
gulp add-example-symlinks will walk every subdir of the ‘_examples’ folder and create a symlinked ‘node_modules’ folder anywhere it finds a ‘package.json’ file.  If there is already a node_modules folder in place, it and all of its children will be deleted before creating the new ‘node_modules’ folder.  The folder being ‘pointed to’ is the node_modules folder in the ‘_examples’ folder.  You will need to run ‘npm install’ in this folder at least once in order to have any node_modules to point to.  You should probably update the package.json in this directory to represent the versions of any dependencies that you want to have as the standard.  Once this is done you will never need to run ‘npm install’ in any of the subdirs, only in the _examples root. 
Important: This gulp task requires admin access on windows but you will probably only need to run it once. I’m not sure of the requirements on a unix system but the code is all standard node. 
That said, what is kind of neat is that if you really want a different set of dependencies for a specific _examples subdir, you can explicitly run ‘npm install’ in the specific folder.  This will in fact update the ‘node_modules’ in the _examples folder ( if you are linked) and your code will operate with the current directory’s package.json settings.  You can then later rerun ‘npm install’ in the _examples folder itself to get everything back to the way it was. 
remove-examples-symlinks
gulp remove-example-symlinks removes all of the symlinks created by ‘add-example-symlinks’.  This task does not need admin access.  One side effect of running add-examples-symlinks followed by remove-example-symlinks is to remove all node_modules completely from the ‘_examples’ subtree. 
Note that neither of these tasks has any effect on the git repo because the only folders changed by any of this are all excluded ‘node_modules’ folder. 
A few other changes were needed to make this work.  First, as you noticed, when you have a lot of node_modules populated a number of our gulp tasks got very slow.  Once I ran the ‘add-example-symlinks’ I started running into this ( as well as crashing WebStorm because it couldn’t handle the depth issue unless I told it to ignore node_modules).  

WebStorm users: remember or learn to exclude node_modules!

I finally traced the  problem with the gulp tasks to the ‘globule’ npm package.  The real issue was that ‘globule’ was walking every file and directory in the _examples folder, including all of the nested node_module folders and then removing the ones with ‘node_modules’ in the path.  I found an alternative ‘globbing’ package (‘globby’) that has a much faster algorithm.   Some tasks went from minutes to seconds once I replaced all use of ‘globule’ with ‘globby’.  I made some of the ‘node_modules’ exclusions more explicit as well.

We did our part. We warned you about the shape of the returned web api result on at least two occasions. For example:

We must also know the shape of the data returned by the server API. We shouldn't expect json() to return the heroes array directly. _The server we're calling always wraps JSON results in an object with a data property_ [emphasis mine]. We have to unwrap it to get the heroes. This is conventional web api behavior, driven by security concerns.

We never said that every http json response is retrieved by res.json().data.   That would be foolish. _No one can tell you how to interpret _every http response.
We said that res.json().data is the way to extract the data from this particular server response.
You are free to complain that your api doesn't do this and that you think this is a bad design. To which I reply without hesitation "you missed the point"  We are rarely lucky enough to face the web api we prefer. It is usually someone else's design, someone with a different notion of what is "right".  The wise developer adapts.

In the real world there is, in fact, an easy way to troubleshoot this (aside from reading the documentation):   send a request to the server and look at what it returns on the network tab of the developer tools. 
In this sample, which intercepts HTTP requests with an in-memory server, the shape of the result is clearly stated in the documentation. You could breakpoint that service if you liked.

Remember that the tour is a gentle introduction to A2. It's meant to reassure the reader that A2 covers the application ground that they need it to cover.  It's not supposed to be comprehensive. It's not supposed to be contentious or risk confusing the reader with choices.

The promise/observable trade-off is the most vexing to me. With my preamble in mind, I think we stick with promises at the boundary between the HeroService and the components. Within the HeroService we talk observables and hint at what's possible there. But I don't want an essay on observables in the ToH.
This is not the place to lead readers on a scary adventure into the uncertainties of observables and other competing data strategies.
There is no reason for ToH to get into the observable weeds. We should say just enough to let the reader know that _we know observables are there_.

Other style points

We use single quotes for strings in our code.
We use less vertical white space and fewer comments than you prefer. I like your approach, especially for your blog. But our chapters are already so huge that we trim that. Another advantage of TypeScript is that the reader can expect more feedback in a supportive IDE so we don't have to tell them how the code works so much.
We always use "we" instead of "you" except in an aside where we're allowing them to go their own way as in "You could do 'x' but we'd rather not".

I carve up the samples with more #docregion tags to focus the discussion more. I often use the +makeTabs plugin to provide the full source code at the bottom when that feels appropriate. I show how in my tweaks.

I really enjoyed reviewing this cookbook. It brought some nagging questions into sharper relief.
The more I looked at it, the more I felt that we remain uncomfortably unclear on the ReactiveForms value proposition.
Frankly, I fail to see anything particularly reactive in the Reactive form approach. We need some insight here that perhaps @kara can supply.
I dispelled the myth that the template approach involves more, ugly HTML.  It seemed to me that myth arises from primitive examples rather than the template approach per se. 
Yes, the primitive examples bake error logic and messages into the HTML as we see in the first example. But this is not an intrinsic defect of the template approach. In my last commit I showed an intermediate Template 2 form that _uses the same validation message code as in the Reactive form example_.  
I aligned code and html for Template 1, Template 2, and Reactive 3 examples such that the reader can see the progression and true differences.
I am troubled by the claim that the reactive approach is easier to test. There isn't any evidence in support of the notion in this example (although there is an opening for a testability claim in my comments below).
AFAIK, the substantive differences between template and reactive approaches are:
1) Reactive defines the form controls in code within the component class; layout and styling remain in html.
2) Reactive defines the validation functions in code within the component class rather than as HTML validation attributes.
My intuition is that developers will find #2 to be the most significant. It also creates an architectural dilemma.  
OTOH, having validation in code rather than attributes has advantages:
- richer validation logic is possible
- the validation logic could be re-factored into the model (or model metadata) rather than hard-coded in the component.
- the validation logic can be tested independently of the component's interaction with its template, especially if refactored into the model.
OTOH, the glaring negative is lack of ARIA support. It's easy but tedious to add that support manually (I updated the sample with a hint in that direction). Ideally the Angular library can do more to be helpful.

Quick answers to your questions:
1) This PR will mention that you cannot change the language dynamically. You must re-load the web page. That's because the language-substitution happens as a compile step, not as the app runs.
This makes sense to me. The facility described here is for static content in the component templates, not live content from a database. Therefore, there is no obvious benefit to re-translating fixed text for every component as it loads. That would make the page slower and heavier.
It seems also a safe bet that users aren't changing language in the middle of their work. A page re-load at the start (if you loaded the wrong version), is a small price for smooth running throughout the session.
2) There is a separate facility, not yet documented, for handling pluralization: i18nPluralPipe. Please give it a try. If you have an issue, please file that on the angular site, not here!

@falconmick Suppose you do eagerly load a module that you formerly loaded lazily? Something "bad" (i.e., breaking) happens ONLY if your feature module deliberately tried to shadow (replace) a provider defined in the root injector. Now you may have a reason to do that! But I'll bet it is rare and that you'll be aware that you did that intentionally ... in which case you will not be tempted to eagerly load that module.
There is very little risk from having a feature-specific provider in the Feature Module promoted to the root injector. Who is going to know? Who (outside of the feature) will inject it?  You can object on purist grounds but there is little to worry about in practice. And if you are a purist, you will have followed my advice to purists and provided the service in the top component for that feature. 
If you added a provider to the root level component (AppComponent), that service will be available to every routed component from an eagerly loaded module.
Lazy loaded modules are different. They do NOT have access to anything provided in the AppComponent (or its subcomponents). They only have access the root injector services (above AppComponent) and the provided services within the context of the lazy loaded module.

Suppose we bound to a single component ... a message component ...
<message-box [message]="currentMessage"></message-box>
How does the MessageBox know when the currentMessage changes?
That's a really important question.
I can think of 2 ways (I learned them from Victor):
1. implement the MessagBox.message as a setter-only property.  The setter method is called when the message changes which is the opportunity for the message box to respond (e.g., by changing the color of the display based on whether the message is a success, warning, or error message).
2. implement ngOnChanges. Angular calls this method when any input value (e.g., the message) changes. 
The first option is usually the simplest. The second option makes more sense when you want to respond to multiple input binding changes and, perhaps, coordinate among them. For example, if our component is bound to departure and arrival date properties, we'd want to know both dates before updating the display (e.g., showing an error if the user would arrive before departure).

. The trouble is that, as far as TypeScript is concerned, the following two declarations are the same symbol:
export interface Attribute { attributeName?: string; }
export const Attribute: AttributeDecorator =
    makeParamDecorator('Attribute', [['attributeName', undefined]]);
It is not clear how we should deal with this. Since TypeScript allows reopening of types, we assumed that multiple declarations for a symbol were for the same type and so we concatenate all the information from the two declarations into a single document, which is why the content field for this document looks like:
Type of the Attribute metadata.\n\n@stable\n\nAttribute decorator and metadata.\n\n@stable\n@Annotation\n\n
Thoughts:
- We could ignore one of the declarations, but which one?
- We create two documents but then they would have the same path and one would end up overwriting the other
- Moreover it seems that now that we have dropped the [Decorator]Metadata term, the current processing to extract decorator docs is going to be broken as it relied on the ...Metadata suffix to find the symbol that contained the information about the properties for the component.

. OK, so here is thing: TypeScript allows "compatible" declarations to be merged into a single symbol. So interface and const can be merged. The resulting symbol has all the symbols of both types.
A type can have a valueDeclaration, which is the first declaration that is a "value" type, e.g. class, function, enum, const, etc, rather than a non-value, such as interface,typedef, etc.
Up to now we just concatenate the docs from each declaration into a single doc, which interestingly is what TypeScript does too - you can see so in the IDE intellisense.
I am going to update the dgeni-packages/typescript package to only take one of the declarations as the primary document, but then attach the other declarations to that doc via an additionalDeclarations property. This should prevent the doc-gen from blowing up and give us access to the other declarations.
The declaration that will be taken for the primary doc will be the valueDeclaration if there is one, or declarations[0] otherwise.

Yes, I have been looking for ways to avoid using too much Jade vs markdown. The limitations we currently face are:
1) While Jade string interpolation #{...} works in markdown, tag interpolation #[...] does not. This is a limitation because mixins can only be interpolated via #[...].
2) The smallest unit of markdown that can be used in conditionals is the paragraph. E.g.
jade
:marked
  some initial text
- if (some condition)
  :marked
    conditionally included text
:marked
  more text
Renders as separate paragraphs like this:

some initial text
conditionally included text
more text

Which is fine when each fragment is meant to be a stand alone paragraph, but sometimes, the prose to be conditionally included is just a word/phrase/statement within a paragraph. Like this:

some initial text conditionally included text more text

To get intra-paragraph conditional inclusion of text requires that we fall back to using Jade elements. It used to be worse, but as I learn more Jade I have been finding better ways of avoiding mixing markdown and Jade elements. Hopefully that will get better over time.

All that being said, the more I work with it the more I find the Jade readable: e.g.
``` jade
:marked
  # Title
Text text text text
  Text text text text
```
in Jade becomes
jade
h1 Title
p.
  Text text text text
  Text text #[code text] text
Which seems as readable, but with one less level of indentation :).

Angular is completely agnostic on which tools to use. Webpack is one option, so is System.js or Rollup. Angular-CLI decided to go to Webpack 2, but that doesn't make Webpack 2 the official bundling tool for Angular, it is just one option and the Angular team works hard on making Angular (and AoT, lazy loading, etc) to work with all bundling tools. Angular-CLI uses webpack 2 officially. But AoT guide documentation uses Rollup for bundling. The objective of the docs is to teach something, and you cannot teach proper AoT with the CLI. CLI does AoT for you automagically, it has a lot of hidden magic and a cookbook saying "To do AoT, please use the --aot flag when building" is not even a tutorial after all. So this mean that we need to teach AoT by hand, that means getting the quickstart and adding everything you need to achieve proper AoT with it. Creating a different main.ts file to load a ngFactory, generate those factories... the idea is to teach people what is this AoT and how to run the tools by hand to achieve the desired result. So why Rollup? We use it for tree shaking and bundling. But again, why? Is just a tool like the others and being honest is the one that does the best tree shaking right now, so it is a good moment to show how it works. Again, this is just to teach AoT, the tool chosen is just one option. We will teach eventually how to configure a Webpack config to do AoT as well, so we cover all the angles. Why? It can give confusion to beginners. It is more confusing if you go directly with the CLI, use they commands they provide to generate AoT and one day it doesn't work and you don't know how it works. Like AoT, our objective is to teach Angular but for teaching Angular we need to use a tool. System.JS works great, the Quickstart gives no issue and does everything you ask it to do. Could we move everything to Webpack? Sure, but then we are in the same spot, why Webpack and not System.js? They are only a necessity, the point is to teach Angular. I think documentation should say that what is best way... The best way is always really subjective. There is no a perfect tool, Webpack is far from being "the tool" and let alone the "best way". Is just one more way. There are people who likes the CLI, people who doesn't. People that prefer to code a Webpack config by hand, people that doesn't want to see Webpack at all. . @billccn that's correct. The interesting point here is that, an annotation is really something that depends on how you define it. Because, what is an annotation? Well, an annotation can be anything that annotates something. Like comments in HTML or CSS code. Or decorators in ES7/TS.
Technically those things are decorators, but on a meta level they are annotations as well, since you're using them to annotate your code. However, on the other hand, the decorators provided by Angular 2 specificly do create annotations. Where as the annotation is really just the annotations and params property on a component.
So to be semantically correct: If you write code in ES7/TS, you use decorators. The things that Angular's decorators create are annotations. Long story short, we us decorators that create annotations.
On a meta level decorators are annotations too.
I think that's also what we should clarify on the website. For more details, I've written an article about exactly that here: http://blog.thoughtram.io/angular/2015/05/03/the-difference-between-annotations-and-decorators.html

Markup consists of a jade file follows the same #docregion #enddocregion conventions as elsewhere.  The comment delimiter for jade files is a ‘//’.  
So in your jade file simply add something like:
// #docregion foo
… jade content
// #enddocregion
All of the capabilities of nested and combined regions are supported here just like elsewhere.
To consume the shared section use the ‘includeShared’ mixin.  It takes two arguments:
+includeShared(filePath, region)
So you could use it from a js jade doc  to point to a section in the ts file in the ts folder with something like this.
+includeShared(‘../../ts/xxx.jade’, ‘foo’)
But because I am assuming that you are going to be sharing with similarly named files across directories there is a shortcut for this.  i.e.  a/b/ts/xx/yy/aaa.jade will be used by a/b/js/xx/yy/aaa.js
+includeShared(‘{ts}’, foo)
The ‘{ts}’ is a shorthand to go up and over and down to the same file in the ‘ts’ subfolder.  Similarly if you wanted to point to a js file from a ts file you would use ‘{js}’.
Side note:  Not needed to use the tool, but be aware that ‘shredding’ jade files does not use the fragments folder but instead shreds in place in the source folder and creates files that begin with ‘_.’

promises vs observables

We know how to use a basic promise to get mock data, but we dont yet know how to get data with http or an observable. Following this pattern it feeds what the reader is craving .... they walk into the chapter wanting to know http, they don't realize they may want Rx later quite yet. So they learn http, see a small mention of  Rx, and then they are primed for the next chapter which will swap out promises for Rx.

. Here is some reasoning here on the problem we are addressing. The number of times we import something is very large in an app. We write import { ... } from ... a lot. Those import statements add up and they can get long. There are a few things we do to make them both less numerous (creating arrays of modules) and to make them shorter (barrels). These add up significantly over time to reduce the code we write and make the app much more readable.
For example, here is how we would import these 4 services in a shared folder without any barrels. Notice spinner and toast are in their own nested folders under shared, too.
import { ExceptionService } from '../app/shared/exception.service';
import { MessageService } from '../app/shared/message.service';
import { SpinnerService } from '../app/shared/spinner/spinner.service';
import { ToastService } from '../app/shared/toast/toast.service';
This is fairly common and the larger an app gets, the more imports we have. Can we do better? If we add barrels with the index.ts file in each folder that exports the symbols, we can now do this:
import { ExceptionService, MessageService } from '../app/shared/index';
import { SpinnerService } from '../app/shared/spinner/index';
import { ToastService } from '../app/shared/toast/index';
That is shorter ... but what if we now use barrels to re-export form the nested folders' barrels too? Then we can make it a single line like this
vs
import { ExceptionService, MessageService, SpinnerService, ToastService } from '../app/shared/index';
And if we are willing to add a map for the folders in systemjs.config.js we can eliminate the need to say /index like this
vs
import { ExceptionService, MessageService, SpinnerService, ToastService } from '../app/shared';
And if we use the CLI it adds the map for us.  
The only Do here is be consistent with whatever technique you want (which will be added to the guide). 
In short:
1. The CLI adds the barrel mapping for us. So we do nothing and we get to say ./shared
2. If we don't use CLI, we map it once in systemjs config, then every import is shorter
3. If we don't like it, we don't do it and instead do ./shared/hero.service
. The real issue here is to see if there is a way to easily omit /index. I propose we add something to the style guide to explain tht the CLI does this for us, but if you don;t use the CLI then you need to add this as a default or import from /index.

src/
  assets/

    assets/

. calling upgrade.bootstrap means that ng1 bootstraps in the wrong zone. For the most part that is not an issue unless there is an eager service in the ng1 bootstrap which pools in ng2 service, which in turn does setTimeout or addEventListener. In that case the async operation is done in the wrong zone. Since most simple hello world examples do not create such scenarios, this only comes into play with more complex apps, which in turn are harder to debug.
The other thing which happens is that people put additional initialization code in the then which also runs the risk of doing wrong outside of angular zone.
The correct thing to do is to always bootstrap in the NgZone.

@sullivanpt some explanation in advance
Singleton in Angular DI is singleton per injector. Each component gets its own injector while each injector (except the root one) is a child-injector of the parent-components injector.
The injector hierarchy therefore mirrors the component hierarchy.
If a dependency is requested from DI, DI searches the DI hierarchy upwards until it finds a provider for the requested dependency. If the injector already issued an instance for this provider previously, the same instance is returned again, otherwise it is created, stored, and returned.
Registering a provider therefore defines the scope for the "singleton".
When a provider is registered only in the root component or bootstrap the scope is the whole application, otherwise the scope is the component where the provider is registered and all its descendants.
If a provider is registered at different levels, the one deeper in the hierarchy overrides the one registered nearer to the root for the component and its descendants because search is from the request upwards until the first is found.
If a provider is registered more than once the issued instance is no application-wide singleton anymore.
Hope this helps. There are of course more details, but I leave that for the Angular team members with more in-depth knowledge.

1. Request / Response interceptors are different. Or at least, they can be defined as separate properties on the interceptor, which means the user-code itself doesn't need to differentiate between the incoming/outgoing when processing actions.
2. The interceptors are setup during the "config" phase.
Now, I know we don't really have a "config" phase in NG2, so maybe putting the setup in the root-component is the way to go. After all, it is the root of the application. 
The other thing that strikes me is the use of .subscribe() as a means to alter an action. Something about that feels strange. When I think about "subscribe" in other aspects, such as RxJS streams, it makes me think that I have access to the "result" of something. In this case, however, the subscribe is to the in-process workflow. Just feels a little odd.

eun-ice:
See https://github.com/angular/angular.io/issues/3137
. This is a serious issue I think.
Fact 1: Sometimes you want to have a private field with a public getter and/or setter. Otherwise using getter/setter would rarely make sense at all.
Fact 2: You cannot have the same name for the getter/setter and a field. Otherwise using this.field=val in the setter or "return this.field" would result in an endless loop.
If you accept both facts you have to accept that you are sometimes required to have different names for a field and a getter, even though they might return the same value.
So you have to rename either the field or the getter/setter.
I see two options
A) prefix private fields with _ (all of them for consistency sake)
B) uppercase getter/setter
With A) already being used by a lot of developers..

- id="name" is the HTML id; AFAIK angular doesn't use it for anything, it's just there to give the label something to point its for attribute to
- [(ngModel)]="model.name" is what you're binding the control to - i.e. the name property of the model property of your component
- name="name" is the HTML field name, which AFAIK angular just uses to register the control w/ the parent form or group (i.e. so you can take an instance of ngForm and get a specific control by name)
- #name="ngModel" is an angular template variable, named name and referencing the instance of the ngModel directive associated with this control. This is the name you see used in the [hidden]="name.valid || name.pristine" expression.
That said, I tend to agree that the naming can very easily get confusing, particularly when you have both template variables and component properties with the same(ish) names. Maybe this is something that should be addressed in the style guide and then implemented throughout the examples?

There is no way to do that outside of using the cli, or at least using the webpack plugin developed for the cli: https://github.com/angular/angular-cli/blob/master/packages/%40ngtools/webpack/src/extract_i18n_plugin.ts which is defined like this: https://github.com/angular/angular-cli/blob/d52d290c80dc06b9f9c42797aceeebe678231fc7/packages/%40angular/cli/models/webpack-configs/xi18n.ts
I've never tried to add it manually to a webpack project outside of the cli though, but I guess that it'll extract the translation files during the compilation ?. Yes it's a wrapper. But what it does is that it runs all the other webpack plugins first to resolve the files, transform them if necessary (for sass files, requires, etc...) so that the ngc compiler can understand the files as if they were regular ts files. It's the same thing that the AoTPlugin does.
the i18n extraction is very similar to the aot compilation, it compiles the application but instead of transforming the templates to js code, it extracts the i18n messages.
I'll try to create a small demo project that uses the extraction without the cli. Ok I've tested to use the plugin on its own with an ejected cli application and it works, you just need to add it to your webpack plugins after the AoTPlugin:
ts
"plugins": [
  // ...
  new AotPlugin({
    "mainPath": "main.ts",
    "i18nFile": "src/i18n/messages.fr.xlf",
    "i18nFormat": "xlf",
    "locale": "fr",
    "replaceExport": false,
    "missingTranslation": "error",
    "hostReplacementPaths": {
      "environments\\environment.ts": "environments\\environment.ts"
    },
    "exclude": [],
    "tsConfigPath": "src\\tsconfig.app.json"
  }),
  new ExtractI18nPlugin({
    "tsConfigPath": "src\\tsconfig.app.json",
    "exclude": [],
    "i18nFormat": "xlf",
    "locale": "fr",
    "outFile": "i18n/test.xlf",
  })
  // ...
]
It will extract the messages when you run the webpack dev server or when you build (in this case it'll extract it into src/i18n/test.xlf). janoc:
This is very much a Fortinet/FortiGate problem - if their appliance is configured for deep inspection, it will try to substitute a forged self-signed certificate (essentially doing a man-in-the-middle attack). Angular.io is using HSTS, so the connection will fail. 
This is a known problem with FortiGate:
http://kb.fortinet.com/kb/documentLink.do?externalID=FD37211
Unfortunately, many of us don't have the choice about having our connection spied on, so we are pretty much screwed :(
. @mbleigh I think nobody can blame you for that. I have managed to get my case solved by hounding the local IT staff to exclude your servers from the FortiGate packet inspection - we are getting our Internet from a municipal connection which has a contract with Fortinet. 
Hopefully I will annoy them sufficiently often (because it isn't only angular.io that doesn't work) that they will disable this spying nonsense for us completely than to have to deal with me again. 
I think the best you can do is to keep this page alive and well document the problem, so that you don't get blamed for problems caused by bogus certificates delivered by this corporate spyware.
. IMO, SSL breaking antiviruses and similar tools that install bogus certificates in your system or try to do man-in-the-middle attacks to allow data inspection are a much bigger problem. It is not long time ago that some major ones were found full of security holes and these bogus certificates are a wonderful backdoor ready for exploitation by malware. 
The antivirus vendors should rather work with browser vendors to obtain hooks where to connect the scanning machinery, if the user so desires. Subverting security for convenience (and siphoning your browsing data for marketing purposes - just read the privacy policy of e.g. Avast or AVG!) is a really bad price to pay for convenience. 
Firebase is not a problem - you would have same issues with Google servers too, for example, if it wasn't for the fact that most antivirus vendors whitelist Google from their inspection attempts.

Even if they don't do anything malicious themselves, companies were hacked, are hacked and will be hacked and data stolen.
